newsitem.title: USA: U.S. shuttle fueled for Tuesday launch.
newsitem.headline: U.S. shuttle fueled for Tuesday launch.

text.p: The U.S. space agency fuelled the space shuttle Columbia for launch on Tuesday, hoping to dodge Florida's notorious afternoon thunderstorms, officials said.
Columbia was to blast off from the Kennedy Space Centre at 1:50 p.m. EDT (1750 GMT), 47 minutes earlier than originally planned.
NASA managers took the unusual step on Monday of moving up the launch time because of a forecast for thunderstorms and rain showers.
"We have the opportunity to launch a little earlier to hopefully get out of town before the thunderstorms show up," shuttle programme manager Tommy Holloway said.
Early on Tuesday, launch controllers loaded the shuttle's giant strap-on fuel tank with a half million gallons of liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen rocket fuel.
U.S. Air Force meteorologists offered an improved weather forecast, giving the shuttle a one-in-three chance of getting off the launch pad on Tuesday.
The best weather was expected at the opening of the shuttle's two and 1/2 hour launch window.
"The bottom line is the earlier we go in the day the better," launch weather officer Scott Jacobs said.
Apart from weather concerns, the shuttle's three-day countdown had been trouble-free and engineers reported no unexpected technical problems.
Columbia and its crew of seven were to make a second attempt at a 16-day research mission that was cut short in April after just five days because of a troublesome power generator.
The shuttle was returned to the launch pad in near-record time for the rerun of the mission, but NASA managers insisted safety was not compromised.
